Boil water and add salt. Pour water (for every cup of rice, use 1 3/4 cups of water) into a large saucepan with a tight-fitting lid. Bring to a boil. Mix 1 teaspoon salt into the water. Pour in rice. Add it to the boiling water. Stir once, or just enough to separate the rice. Use a wooden spoon to separate any clumps.

1 To cook wild rice: Use 1 cup of rice to 3 cups of water. 2  Bring the water to a boil, reduce the heat, and simmer for 45 minutes. 3  Let stand, covered, for 10 minutes before serving. 4  To cook rice pilaf: For pilaf dishes, rice is sauteed in oil in order to keep the grains separate during cooking. 1 To cook brown rice: Use 1 cup of rice and 2 cups of water. 2  Bring the water to a boil, reduce the heat, and simmer for 45 minutes. 3  Let stand, covered, for 10 minutes before serving. 4  To cook basmati or jasmine rice: Follow the instructions for long-grained white rice

Transfer the rice to your rice cooker and let it soak for about 45 minutes in 2 2/3 cups (580 ml) warm water. 1  Soaking is beneficial because it reduces the stickiness of the rice. 2  It also helps the rice expand into long, thin grains. 3  You can soak the rice up to 3 hours, if desired, but 45 minutes will often be enough. If your rice cooker has a brown rice setting, use that. If it only has a timer, set the timer for 30 minutes. 1  Cover the rice cooker before starting it and leave that cover on for the duration of the cooking process. 2  The rice and quinoa may need a total of 40 minutes to finish cooking inside the rice cooker.

Measure the rice with a cup and put it into your cooking pot. Some rice cookers have a removable bowl or pot, while others must have the rice placed directly in the cooker. Most of the time, rice cookers will come with a measuring cup or scoop that can fit 3/4 cup (180 mL). If your rice cooker has a removable cooking pot, place the pot of rice and water back into the rice cooker. Close the lid of the cooker, plug the cooker in, and press the switch to turn it on. The switch will click, like a toaster, when the rice is done.
